intro: Silene tenuis var. dentata, commonly known as the narrowleaf catchfly, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is characterized by its slender, branching stems and small, pinkish-white flowers that bloom in late summer. The leaves are linear and often have subtle teeth along the margins, giving it its specific variety name. It thrives in dry, sandy soils and is often found in open habitats such as grasslands and rocky areas. This species is part of the Caryophyllaceae family, known for its showy flowers and succulent stems.
